t: Judges 5
The Song of Deborah and Barak
Then*p Deborah and Barak the son of Abinoam sang on that day, saying,
“That*pn the leaders led in Israel, That*ln the people volunteered, Bless*ln the Lord!*s
Hear,*ln O kings; give ear, O rulers! I—to*ln the Lord,*s I will sing, I*ln will sing praise to the Lord,*s the God of Israel.
Lord,*sln when You went out from Seir, When*ln You marched from the field of Edom, The*ln earth quaked, the heavens also dripped, Even*ln the clouds dripped water.
The*ln mountains quaked at the presence of the Lord,*s This*ln Sinai, at the presence of the Lord,*s the God of Israel.
“In*ln the days of Shamgar the son of Anath, In*ln the days of Jael, the highways were deserted, And*ln travelers went by roundabout ways.
The*ln peasantry ceased, they ceased in Israel, Until*ln I, Deborah, arose, Until*ln I arose, a mother in Israel.
New*ln gods were chosen; Then*ln war was*i in the gates. Not*ln a shield or a spear was seen Among*ln forty thousand in Israel.
My*ln heart goes*i out*i to the commanders of Israel, The*ln volunteers among the people; Bless*ln the Lord!*s
You*ln who ride on white donkeys, You*ln who sit on rich*i carpets, And*ln you who travel on the road—sing!

At*ln the sound of those who divide flocks*i among the watering places, There*ln they shall recount the righteous deeds of the Lord,*s The*ln righteous deeds for His peasantry in Israel. Then*ln the people of the Lord*s went down to the gates.
“Awake,*ln awake, Deborah; Awake,*ln awake, sing a song! Arise,*ln Barak, and take away your captives, O son of Abinoam.
Then*ln survivors came down to the nobles; The*ln people of the Lord*s came down to me as warriors.

From*ln Ephraim those whose root is in Amalek came*i down,*i Following*ln you, Benjamin, with your peoples; From*ln Machir commanders came down, And*ln from Zebulun those who wield the staff of office.

And*ln the princes of Issachar were*i with Deborah; As*ln was*i Issachar, so was*i Barak; Into*ln the valley they rushed at his heels; Among*ln the divisions of Reuben There*iln were*i great resolves of heart.
Why*ln did you sit among the sheepfolds, To*ln hear the piping for the flocks? Among*ln the divisions of Reuben There*iln were*i great searchings of heart.
Gilead*ln remained across the Jordan; And*ln why did Dan stay in ships? Asher*ln sat at the seashore, And*ln remained by its landings.
Zebulun*ln was*i a people who despised their lives even*i to death, And*ln Naphtali also, on the high places of the field.
“The*ln kings came and*i fought; Then*ln fought the kings of Canaan At*ln Taanach near the waters of Megiddo; They*ln took no plunder in silver.
The*ln stars fought from heaven, From*ln their courses they fought against Sisera.
The*ln torrent of Kishon swept them away, The*ln ancient torrent, the torrent Kishon. O*ln my soul, march on with strength.
Then*ln the horses’ hoofs beat From*ln the dashing, the dashing of his valiant steeds.
‘Curse*ln Meroz,’ said the angel of the Lord,*s ‘Utterly*ln curse its inhabitants; Because*ln they did not come to the help of the Lord,*s To*ln the help of the Lord*s against the warriors.’
“Most*ln blessed of women is Jael, The*ln wife of Heber the Kenite; Most*ln blessed is she of women in the tent.
He*ln asked for water and*i she gave him milk; In*ln a magnificent bowl she brought him curds.
She*ln reached out her hand for the tent peg, And*ln her right hand for the workmen’s hammer. Then*ln she struck Sisera, she smashed his head; And*ln she shattered and pierced his temple.
Between*ln her feet he bowed, he fell, he lay; Between*ln her feet he bowed, he fell; Where*ln he bowed, there he fell dead.
“Out*ln of the window she looked and lamented, The*ln mother of Sisera through the lattice, ‘Why*ln does his chariot delay in coming? Why*ln do the hoofbeats of his chariots tarry?’
Her*ln wise princesses would answer her, Indeed*ln she repeats her words to herself,

‘Are*ln they not finding, are they not dividing the spoil? A*ln maiden, two maidens for every warrior; To*ln Sisera a spoil of dyed work, A*ln spoil of dyed work embroidered, Dyed*ln work of double embroidery on the neck of the spoiler?’
Thus*ln let all Your enemies perish, O Lord;*s But*ln let those who love Him be like the rising of the sun in its might.” And*p the land was undisturbed for forty years.
